entries.title: Putting a price tag on nature failed. Can radical tactics save it?
entries.content: Biologists have long thought that speaking to nature’s economic value would persuade boardrooms it was worth saving. It hasn’t worked – so what, if anything, will?

entries.title: Why adding cross training into your exercise routine is the way to go
entries.content: There are huge benefits to ringing the changes when it comes to exercise, finds committed runner Grace Wade when she analyses the science

entries.title: How teaching molecules to think is revealing what a 'mind' really is
entries.content: Networks of molecules in our body behave as though they have goals and desires. Understanding this phenomenon could solve the origins of life and mind in one fell swoop

entries.title: Exploring sci-fi treats from George Saunders and Matthew Kressel
entries.content: In George Saunders's Vigil, a ghost visits Earth to help a dying oil tycoon, while terraforming efforts on Mars are about to bear fruit in The Rainseekers by Matthew Kressel. Emily H. Wilson's sci-fi column explores two very different short novels

entries.title: Your BMI can't tell you much about your health – here's what can
entries.content: People classed as “overweight” according to BMI can be perfectly healthy. But there are better measures of fat, and physicians are finally using them

entries.title: These 5 diets could add years to your life even if you have bad genes
entries.content: Five dietary patterns that involve eating lots of plants have been linked with living up to three years longer, even among people who are genetically predisposed to have a shorter life

entries.title: World’s oldest cold virus found in 18th-century woman's lungs
entries.content: Finding rhinoviruses, which cause the common cold, in preserved medical specimens and analysing their RNA genome could let us trace the evolution of human illness

entries.title: Huge hot blobs inside Earth may have made its magnetic field wonky
entries.content: Simulations suggest that two enormous masses of hot rock have been involved in generating Earth’s magnetic field and giving it an irregular shape

entries.title: Accidental discovery hints at mystery structures within our brain
entries.content: Scientists may have stumbled across a network of vessels in the brain that helps clear out waste fluid – a discovery that could "represent a paradigm shift in our understanding of all neurodegenerative diseases"

entries.title: First ever inhalable gene therapy for cancer gets fast-tracked by FDA
entries.content: A gene therapy that patients breathe in has been found to shrink lung tumours by inserting immune-boosting genes into surrounding cells

entries.title: CAR T-cell therapy may slow neurodegenerative conditions like ALS
entries.content: Immune cells in the brain that go rogue contribute to the death of neurons, so getting rid of them may slow the progression of neurodegenerative conditions like amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

entries.title: New Scientist recommends Hamnet, and its look at our links with nature
entries.content: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

entries.title: Gene editing that spreads within the body could cure more diseases
entries.content: The idea of self-amplifying gene editing is to get cells to pass on packages of CRISPR machinery to their neighbours, boosting the effect

entries.title: Why self-expansion is the key to long-lasting love and friendship
entries.content: A growing body of psychological research shows that the best relationships – romantic or otherwise – come with a feeling of personal growth. Columnist David Robson explores the evidence-backed ways to broaden our horizons and connect more deeply with our loves, our friends and ourselves

entries.title: RNA strand that can almost self-replicate may be key to life's origins
entries.content: Life may have begun when RNA molecules began to replicate themselves, and now we’ve finally found an RNA molecule that is very close to being able to do this

entries.title: Weird inside-out planet system may have formed one world at a time
entries.content: The planets around a nearby star seem to be in the wrong order, hinting that they formed through a different mechanism than the familiar one by which most systems grow

entries.title: Endurance brain cells may determine how long you can run for
entries.content: The activity of certain neurons may influence our endurance for exercise, and these could be targeted to help us run faster for longer

entries.title: Why I'm still an environmental optimist – despite it all
entries.content: It's hard not to despair about the state of the world today, but here are five reasons to be a little bit hopeful, says Fred Pearce

entries.title: The surprising origins of Britain's Bronze Age immigrants revealed
entries.content: About 4600 years ago, the population of Britain was replaced by a people who brought Bell Beaker pottery with them. Now, ancient DNA has uncovered the murky story of where these people came from

entries.title: This state’s power prices are plummeting as it nears 100% renewables
entries.content: South Australia is proving to the world that relying largely on wind and solar energy with battery back-up is incredibly cheap, with electricity prices tumbling by 30 per cent in a year and sometimes going negative

entries.title: Royal Navy returns to wind power with trial of robotic sailboats
entries.content: A fleet of wind-propelled robot boats could act as a sensor network covering a wide area and relay acoustic signals to a submarine

entries.title: 'Roughly 109.5 golden retrievers': a new way to measure ice
entries.content: Feedback is always on the lookout for better ways to measure things, and was delighted to learn how the weight of ice is quantified in Austin, Texas

entries.title: What to read this week: Bonded by Evolution by Paul Eastwick
entries.content: We are told we need cynical strategies to "play" the dating game, but the science says this is totally wrong. David Robson enjoys an evidence-based takedown from psychologist Paul Eastwick

entries.title: Nepal and Northern India are not overdue for a huge earthquake
entries.content: Many researchers thought that earthquakes in the Himalayas recur at regular intervals – but an analysis of sediment cores has shown they are largely random, and the region has seen far more than we previously realised

entries.title: Ancient Peruvian civilisation grew mighty by harvesting guano
entries.content: The Chincha Kingdom was transporting seabird excrement from islands to valleys as early as the 13th century, and this powerful fertiliser may have been key to its economic success

entries.title: Gravitational wave signal proves Einstein was right about relativity
entries.content: Ripples in space-time from a pair of merging black holes have been recorded in unprecedented detail, enabling physicists to test predictions of general relativity

entries.title: Newborn marsupials seen crawling to mother's pouch for the first time
entries.content: Scientists have captured remarkable footage of the young of a mouse-sized marsupial, called a fat-tailed dunnart, making their way to their mother’s pouch soon after being born

entries.title: Which humans first made tools or art – and how do we know?
entries.content: Building the human story based on a few artefacts is tricky – particularly for wooden tools that don’t preserve well, or cave art that we don’t have the technology to date. Columnist Michael Marshall explores how we determine what came first in the timeline of our species

entries.title: Time crystals could be used to build accurate quantum clocks
entries.content: Once considered an oddity of quantum physics, time crystals could be a good building block for accurate clocks and sensors, according to new calculations

entries.title: Old EV batteries could meet most of China's energy storage needs
entries.content: Electric vehicle batteries are typically retired once they reach about 80 per cent of their original capacity, but they could be repurposed in electricity grids to balance out slumps in renewable generation

entries.title: Why 1.5°C failed and setting a new limit would make things worse
entries.content: Setting a limit for global warming didn't succeed in galvanising climate action quickly enough – now we should focus on making the annual average temperature rise clear for all to see, says Bill McGuire

entries.title: How clinical research is still failing underrepresented communities
entries.content: As a doctor working in genomic research, I know that we lack vital data for Black people and many other groups. Here's how we can change that, says Drews Adade

entries.title: Specific cognitive training has 'astonishing' effect on dementia risk
entries.content: A type of cognitive training that tests people's quick recall seems to reduce the risk of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease

entries.title: Is this carved rock an ancient Roman board game?
entries.content: The lines worn into an engraved limestone object from the Netherlands are consistent with the idea that it was a Roman game board, according to an AI analysis

entries.title: 'Hidden' group of gut bacteria may be essential to good health
entries.content: Scientists have pinpointed a group of bacteria that consistently appear in high numbers in healthy people, suggesting that these could one day be targeted through diet or probiotics

entries.title: Jeff Goldblum should make a film about this legendary mathematician
entries.content: Paul Erdős was one of the most prolific mathematicians to ever live, known for showing up at the door of others in the field and declaring they should host and feed him while they do maths together. His radical life should be immortalised by Hollywood in a comedy biopic, says columnist Jacob Aron

entries.title: Physicists can now take control of 'hidden' friction in devices
entries.content: One type of friction can waste energy even when two perfectly smooth surfaces move against each other, but researchers are getting a handle on how to attenuate or stop it completely

entries.title: Personalised medicine is yet to deliver, but that must start to change
entries.content: Companies are happy to sell you personalised tracking of your biomarkers or a tailored nutrition plan, but truly personalised medicine should be able to tackle the vast differences some people have in response to the same diseases

entries.title: Statins don't cause most of the side effects listed on their labels
entries.content: A review of the evidence suggests that statins are no more likely than a placebo to cause most of the side effects listed on their labels

entries.title: Seafarers were visiting remote Arctic islands over 4000 years ago
entries.content: The first people to reach the Kitsissut Islands off the north-west coast of Greenland were Indigenous peoples, who crossed over 50 kilometres of treacherous water

entries.title: Why is childbirth so hard for humans – and is it getting even harder?
entries.content: Some think the rise of C-sections means that one day all births will require serious medical intervention. But a surprising new understanding of the pelvis suggests a different story

entries.title: Do weeds really love poor soil? Not if you look at the science
entries.content: It's a truism that weeds love poor soil, but is there anything to it? And what is a weed, anyway? James Wong investigates

entries.title: Nobel laureate says he'll build world’s most powerful quantum computer
entries.content: John Martinis has already revolutionised quantum computing twice. Now, he is working on another radical rethink of the technology that could deliver machines with unrivalled capabilities

entries.title: The Beauty may be horror TV but it misses the genre's point
entries.content: In The Beauty, mysterious deaths of models are linked to a new drug and a sexually transmitted infection, both of which kill as they beautify. But if you want great body horror, this isn't the place to look, concludes Bethan Ackerley

entries.title: Weakening ice shelf has caused crucial Antarctic glacier to accelerate
entries.content: The flow of ice at Pine Island Glacier in West Antarctica has sped up dramatically due to the disintegration of the ice shelf in front of it, and this could lead to faster sea level rise

entries.title: Physicists warn of 'catastrophic' impact from UK science cuts
entries.content: Science funding cuts in the UK are expected to be a "devastasting blow" for physics research, affecting international projects such as particle detection experiments at CERN

entries.title: The secret signals our organs send to repair tissues and slow ageing
entries.content: Your organs are constantly talking to each other in ways we’re only beginning to understand. Tapping into these communication networks is opening up radical new ways to boost health

entries.title: Why exercise isn't much help if you are trying to lose weight
entries.content: When we exercise more, our bodies may compensate by using less energy for other things – especially if we eat less too

entries.title: Synchronised volcanic eruptions on Io hint at a spongy interior
entries.content: Five volcanoes on Jupiter’s moon Io erupted simultaneously, spewing a mind-boggling amount of lava onto the surface and giving us clues to what may lie underneath

entries.title: New Scientist recommends 28 Years Later: The Bone Temple
entries.content: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

entries.title: Moving inductions to early morning could shorten labour by 6 hours
entries.content: By matching uterine contractions up with the body’s natural circadian rhythms, inducing labour in the early morning is linked to shorter labour and fewer emergency C-sections

entries.title: Sebastião Salgado's stunning shots of the world's icy regions
entries.content: The late photographer's work depicting some of the world's coldest places is collected in his new book Genesis

entries.title: A new 'brief history' of the universe paints a wide picture
entries.content: Nearly 40 years after Stephen Hawking's A Brief History of Time, Sarah Alam Malik's epic exploration of the cosmos reflects a changed landscape around science in the 21st century, finds Alison Flood

entries.title: Five stunning images from the Close-up Photographer of the Year awards
entries.content: An otherworldly coral, a very cute moth and an intricately beautiful mushroom are among the winners in the prize this year

entries.title: The toxic burden of pesticides is growing all around the world
entries.content: Pesticides are becoming more toxic and just about every country is using more of them year after year, despite a UN target to halve the overall risk by 2030

entries.title: Methane surge in 2020 was linked to lower pollution during lockdowns
entries.content: A change in atmospheric chemistry during the covid pandemic resulted in methane concentrations spiking, raising concerns that cleaning up pollution could have similar knock-on effects in the future

entries.title: Bonobo's pretend tea party shows capacity for imagination
entries.content: Kanzi, a bonobo with exceptional language skills, took part in a make-believe tea party that demonstrated cognitive abilities never seen before in non-human primates

entries.title: Fast-charging quantum battery built inside a quantum computer
entries.content: An experiment with superconducting qubits opens the door to determining whether quantum devices could be less energetically costly if they are powered by quantum batteries

entries.title: Nasal spray could prevent infections from any flu strain
entries.content: An antibody that has the power to neutralise any influenza strain could be widely administered in the form of a nasal spray if a flu pandemic emerges

entries.title: Vegan toddlers can grow at the same rate as omnivores
entries.content: Two-year-olds raised in vegan or vegetarian households don't necessarily have restricted growth, according to a study of 1.2 million children

entries.title: How to live a meaningful life, according to science
entries.content: The meaning of life has puzzled philosophers for millennia, but new research suggests it could be as simple as lending a helping hand

entries.title: Why Elon Musk has misunderstood the point of Star Trek
entries.content: As Elon Musk and Pete Hegseth talk about wanting to make Star Trek real, long-time fan Chanda Prescod-Weinstein says they've misconstrued the heart of the story

entries.title: Holy prosociality! Batman makes people stand for pregnant passengers
entries.content: Feedback is delighted by an experiment on the Milan metro system, which involved a prosthetic bump, a Batman costume and some unexpected displays of public decency

entries.title: Unexpectedly moving book makes the case for the Arctic
entries.content: In his lyrical book Frostlines, Neil Shea argues that we are more connected to the Arctic than we might think, says Elle Hunt

entries.title: Psychedelic causes similar brain state to meditation
entries.content: The psychedelic 5-MeO-DMT seemed to induce similar patterns of brain activity in a lama - a revered spiritual teacher in Tibetan Buddhism - as meditation, advancing our understanding of the drug's neurological effects

entries.title: A social network for AI looks disturbing, but it's not what you think
entries.content: A social network where humans are banned and AI models talk openly of world domination has led to claims that the "singularity" has begun, but the truth is that much of the content is written by humans

entries.title: Record-breaking quantum simulator could unlock new materials
entries.content: An array of 15,000 qubits made from phosphorus and silicon offers an unprecedentedly large platform for simulating quantum materials such as perfect conductors of electricity

entries.title: Forever chemical TFA has tripled due to ozone-preserving refrigerants
entries.content: Chemicals used in refrigeration break down in the atmosphere to produce trifluoroacetic acid, a persistent pollutant that could be harmful to humans and aquatic life

entries.title: Treating cancer before 3pm could help patients live longer
entries.content: The most robust evidence to date shows that people with a type of lung cancer lived longer if they received immunotherapy before 3pm

entries.title: Dutch air force reads pilots' brainwaves to make training harder
entries.content: While pilots are flying in a VR simulation, their brainwave patterns can be fed into an AI model that assesses how challenging they are finding a task and adjusts the difficulty accordingly

entries.title: The weird rules of temperature get even stranger in the quantum realm
entries.content: Can a single particle have a temperature? It may seem impossible with our standard understanding of temperature, but columnist Jacklin Kwan finds that it’s not exactly ruled out in the quantum realm

entries.title: Why did SpaceX just apply to launch 1 million satellites?
entries.content: SpaceX says it wants to deploy an astronomical number of data centres in orbit to supply power for artificial intelligence, but the proposal might not be entirely serious

entries.title: Neanderthals and early humans may have interbred over a vast area
entries.content: We are getting a clearer sense of where and how often Homo sapiens and Neanderthals interbred, and it turns out the behaviour was much more common than we first thought

entries.title: Ants attack their nest-mates because pollution changes their smell
entries.content: Ants rely on scent to recognise their comrades, and when they are exposed to common air pollutants, other members of their colony react as if they are enemies

entries.title: Melatonin gummies as sleep aids for children: What are the risks?
entries.content: To eliminate bedtime struggles, a growing number of parents have turned to melatonin gummies, but these hormone supplements are largely unregulated. Columnist Alice Klein digs into the evidence on the risks of regularly using melatonin as a sleep aid for children

entries.title: A huge cloud of dark matter may be lurking near our solar system
entries.content: For the first time, researchers have found what seems to be a cloud of dark matter about 60 million times the mass of the sun in our galactic neighbourhood

entries.title: It would be a mistake to rush into an under-16 social media ban
entries.content: Many countries are debating whether to follow Australia and ban social media for younger teenagers. But with more robust evidence on its harms coming, we shouldn't be too hasty

entries.title: Why people can have Alzheimer's-related brain damage but no symptoms
entries.content: Some people don’t develop dementia despite showing signs of Alzheimer’s disease in their brain, and we're starting to understand why

entries.title: CRISPR grapefruit without the bitterness are now in development
entries.content: Gene-editing citrus fruits to make them less bitter could not only encourage more people to eat them, it might also help save the industry from a devastating plague

entries.title: Nobel prizewinner Omar Yaghi says his invention will change the world
entries.content: Chemist Omar Yaghi invented materials called MOFs, a few grams of which have the surface area of a football field. He explains why he thinks these super-sponges will define the next century

entries.title: The best new popular science books of February 2026
entries.content: Readers are spoiled for choice when it comes to popular science reading this month, with new titles by major names including Maggie Aderin and Michael Pollan

entries.title: Bored of snakes and ladders? Some maths can help bring back the fun
entries.content: While snakes and ladders is purely a game of chance, there is a way to add some strategy, says mathematician Peter Rowlett

entries.title: Ancient humans were seafaring far earlier than we realised
entries.content: Thousands of years before the invention of compasses or sails, prehistoric peoples crossed oceans to reach remote lands like Malta and Australia. Doing so meant striking out in unknowable conditions. What do such crossings tell us about ancient minds?

entries.title: A remarkable book on quantum mechanics reveals a really big idea
entries.content: Where is physics headed? No one knows for sure, but Beyond the Quantum by Antony Valentini is a striking new book that reminds us what a big idea really looks like, finds Jon Cartwright

entries.title: The daring idea that time is an illusion and how we could prove it
entries.content: The way time ticks forward in our universe has long stumped physicists. Now, a new set of tools from entangled atoms to black holes promises to reveal time’s true nature

entries.title: Can we genetically improve humans using George Church’s famous list?
entries.content: Columnist Michael Le Page delves into a catalogue of hundreds of potentially beneficial gene mutations and variants that is popular with transhumanists

entries.title: Elon Musk is making a big bet on his future vision – will it work?
entries.content: Reports suggest that Elon Musk is eyeing up a merger involving SpaceX, Tesla and xAI, but what does he hope to achieve by consolidating his business empire?

entries.title: Yawning has an unexpected influence on the fluid inside your brain
entries.content: Yawning and deep breathing each have different effects on the movement of fluids in the brain, and each of us may have a distinct yawning "signature"

entries.title: The best new science fiction books of February 2026
entries.content: We pick the sci-fi novels we’re most looking forward to reading this month, from a new Brandon Sanderson to the latest from Makana Yamamoto

entries.title: How an 1800s vaccine drive beat smallpox in Denmark in just 7 years
entries.content: In the early 1800s, Denmark’s government, medical community, church leaders and school teachers all united to promote the new smallpox vaccine, which led to a remarkably quick elimination of the disease in the capital

entries.title: Our verdict on Annie Bot: This novel about a sex robot split opinions
entries.content: Members of the New Scientist Book Club give their take on Sierra Greer's award-winning science-fiction novel Annie Bot, our read for February – and the needle swings wildly from positive to negative

entries.title: Read an extract from Juice by Tim Winton
entries.content: In this extract from the February read for the New Scientist Book Club, we meet the protagonist of Tim Winton’s Juice, driving across a scorched landscape in a future version of Australia

entries.title: Tim Winton: 'Sometimes I think we use the word dystopia as an opiate'
entries.content: The New Scientist Book Club's February read is Tim Winton's novel Juice, set in a future Australia that is so hot it is almost unliveable. Here, the author lays out his reasons for writing it – and why he doesn't see it as dystopian

entries.title: New Scientist recommends pioneering artist Ryoji Ikeda's new work
entries.content: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

entries.title: The universe may be hiding a fundamentally unknowable quantum secret
entries.content: Even given a set of possible quantum states for our cosmos, it's impossible for us to determine which one of them is correct

entries.title: This virus infects most of us – but why do only some get very ill?
entries.content: The ubiquitous Epstein-Barr virus is increasingly being linked to conditions like multiple sclerosis and lupus. But why do only some people who catch it develop these complications? The answer may lie in our genetics

entries.title: This doctor is on the hunt for people with first-rate faeces
entries.content: Elizabeth Hohmann is very interested in faeces, and spends her days sifting through stools to find those that could make the biggest difference to other people's health

entries.title: Fascinating but flawed book explores how sickness shapes our lives
entries.content: Susan Wise Bauer's The Great Shadow investigates the effects of illness on individual lives and collective beliefs. It's a mixed bag, says Peter Hoskin

entries.title: AI-assisted mammograms cut risk of developing aggressive breast cancer
entries.content: Interval cancers are aggressive tumours that grow during the interval after someone has been screened for cancer and before they are screened again, and AI seems to be able to identify them at an early stage

entries.title: Our lifespans may be half down to genes and half to the environment
entries.content: A reanalysis of twin data from Denmark and Sweden suggests that how long we live now depends roughly equally on the genes we inherit, and on where we live and what we do
